author: issa.ichikawa
title: Startups & Onboarding for Students
description: How can we support student blockchain startups through Catalyst? And how can I increase the number of student Catalyst proposers and blockchain engineers?

f6_assessments.q0:
The purpose of this challenge setting is to give space to student startups on Catalyst.

Developing a public blockchain like Cardano and a robust developer ecosystem requires many contributors/developers. There is an underexplored workforce in universities and colleges that could be used on Cardano. This challenge intends to fill this hole, however one of the minimum requirements defined is the existence of only one student in the team of a proposal, which in practice could result in several teams including one student, of random course, just to fulfill the requirements. The concept of this challenge setting is interesting but I don't believe this requirement is aligned with the objective of this challenge setting, as the requirement could easily be circumvented.

Considering the fact that there is already space for student projects on Catalyst, I do not agree that this challenge setting is critical in the Cardano mission, but I see that it is an important and relevant topic.

This challenge setting is in line with the item 1 of the Catalyst Fund9 Challenge Setting Strategic Goals mentioned in the Proposal Assessor Guide.
f6_assessments.q1: This challenge has no technical challenges that limit the community's ability to contribute, it just has a simple requirement to include at least one student in the team, which also does not significantly limit the ability to contribute.The budget is relatively low compared to the other challenge settings, so there is no tendency for low demand and low budget requested/total available budget ratio.
f6_assessments.q2:
The definition of success is not appropriate for the context presented in this challenge setting. Reducing competition and limiting the budget are hard requirements of the challenge setting, therefore, all proposals are expected to comply with this definition. The definition of success needs to indicate the outcome of the proposals over time in relation to the challenge and not whether they meet the requirements of the challenge setting.

4 key metrics were included, but I do not consider them appropriate to measure the success of this challenge.Number of proposals, applause and comments are relevant  indicators of demand in the challenge and engagement, but they say little about the work and development of proposals as startup projects an their contribution to the ecosystem.
 Number of collaborations is a relevant indicator. Key metrics are missing to assess the quality of projects and proposals after funding and how they are delivering what is expected by the concept of this challenge. Would it also be important to provide a time frame for evaluating when key metrics and success will be measured? 6 months? 12 months? It is important to establish a time frame to make verification appropriate.

f6_assessments.q0:
Onboarding students by creating specific challenge for students is beneficial to Cardano ecosystem. In the way of the challenge's setup, I can agree and understand that by limiting the challenge to Students, it is a way to limit the competition but in a positive way. The experience that this challenge creates, with competence and trust, funded students can be prepared to create bigger projects in other challenges in future funding rounds. Students can bring young, creative and engaging new members into the ecosystem.

This challenge can be an ongoing onboarding challenge for students around the world. The challenge certainly supports Cardano's mission, and supports directly two fund9 strategic goals. I strongly agree that this challenge can bring good positive progress in Cardano's mission for change and progress.
f6_assessments.q1:
The Cardano community most definitely has the capacity to address this challenge. Within Catalyst community, there are many students and members of the higher education, who have direct connection to the broader community of education around the world.

The budget for this challenge set to 100k USD, with a reasonable decision by the challenge members to limit the funding raised by each challenge proposer to 10k USD. By setting the budget cap, the challenge team expects to support at least 10 students (teams), that will be able to raise funds. The challenge brief suggests to the students to submit small proposals to this category and see if their idea makes enough traction to make future bigger projects.
Everything seems to be well thought of within this challenge, for feasibility I can strongly agree that this challenge will be a successful one.

The challenge team members are well known members of the Catalyst community, Eastern Town Hall members, with direct connection to the Waseda University in Japan. Both members share the role of Cardano Ambassador, Catalyst funding round participation, SPO, Certified accountant, representative of multiple Catalyst challenge teams.
f6_assessments.q2:
First off, this challenge setting is, as it seems, a translated one from Japanese language. With that said, I must urge the challenge members, to work on and fix the Key metrics, presented under this challenge. The first one, "Number of proposals for this category”, is ok. The 2nd one, "Number of applause and comments from the community", to not go deep into it, I would scratch this one completely. Maybe the meaning of it is lost in the translation. If the challenge member's idea was to measure the social engagement within the community, comments from the community, or any exchange like that, is not a factual way of measuring success of this challenge. My suggestion is to focus on things that can clearly be identified as a definite success of this challenge, or the teams proposing their projects successfully within the challenge. The third metric, "Number of collaborations with other proposers", this one touches on the suggested focus. 4th, "Number of proposals that participated in the next round", this one is not clear to me what is meant to describe exactly, perhaps another one lost in translation, please try to rephrase, or edit this one.

The challenge brief makes it easier for the new proposers to identify with this challenge, it is well-structured and written. Students can apply who already have a business idea and are looking for funding for their startup. Development ideas, education programs (seminars, content translation, hubs), leveraging student experience is the main driver of this challenge.

f6_assessments.q0:
As someone who has been trying to persuade university students and head of faculties from the three best universities of my community, I have continuously found that students are almost always crippled by the feeling of inadequacy seeing how there are many technically sophisticated proposals which are written in perfect or better English than the students. They have this fear of failing, of embarrassment. Perhaps it is a cultural specific attitude, perhaps it is a character related phenomenon, what is interesting is, that it is prevalent amongst students. Where the general conceptions are that students, specifically university students are encouraged to explore, to develop and to fail forward.

By creating this specific challenge, although it is not mentioned specifically in this proposal, of the importance of failing forward, it creates a safe zone for students to gradually learn and build confidence to submit more intricate and more financially demanding proposals. Having specific goals also creates clarity for these potential students and also for the larger Cardano community on what does this Challenge Setting seek to achieve and provide cover of. Therefore there should be limited misconception between the general Cardano community and the students proposals.

There is this lingering notion that we should focus on the current crop of available developers, which suggests that the language used by Cardano is universally prevalent and available all around the globe. This is a mindset that is Western Hemisphere oriented. Although Japan, Korea and Taiwan are advanced countries, the number of Cardano developers coming out of these nations are alarmingly limited. Let us take the example of Japan, the largest holder and supporter of Cardano, yet they do not have a thriving Cardano ecosystem. This proposal can slowly change that. They keyword here would be "slowly".

Learning Cardano is tough. The syllabus developed by Lars, which takes 10-12 weeks to finish has a high drop-out rate in general. By allowing students to onboard themselves in ways they see fit, and supervised by the general Cardano community, we can slowly guide our way to finding bespoke education solutions that is by the students for the students, which hopefully ensures more success.
f6_assessments.q1:
We have a number of available and prominent Cardano developers from the community, taking shape in the form of Gimbalabs, whom are dedicated in providing free education on Cardano. We also have the individuals from EBU, who are integrated throughout the larger Cardano community, providing education materials and syllabus on Haskell and Plutus. There is no shortage of helping hands who can further the impact and effectiveness of this Challenge Setting and the potential proposals that will come of it. Emurgo themselves has setup an academy to assist proposer in creating proposals for Project Catalyst.

There is no doubt on our capacity as a community to nurture and provide guidance for proposers in this Challenge Setting. Though this should be taken with a grain of salt, for at Project Catalyst current state it only effectively supports English speaking proposers. Support of various languages are in place but would take time to mature. Which this proposal sets itself to address.
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposals Success Criteria though, is more focused on producing proposals. It is not a mission driven Challenge Setting, more metric driven. The metrics used are mostly addressing "the number of proposals". Although this is well, having a balance between quantity and quality would have been more effective. Perhaps in the metrics that are intended to be achieved, it could be added on metrics such as ; the number of proposal from leading universities, or the topics of proposals that focus on blockchain education, or proposals that addresses key topics of Cardano development. 

By having specific guidance, we not only address the need of onboarding students, but we also guide them to address key issues in Cardano which then bolsters the effectiveness of this Challenge Setting in the eyes of the general Cardano community.

f6_assessments.q0: The goal of this proposal is to create a challenge exclusive to start-ups created by students who want to build their projects using Cardano as a platform. The budget of the proposals would be limited to $10k, and the proposing team expects at least 10 proposals funded. Although, I believe there was some confusion since from Fund 10 the budget of each challenge is requested in ADA, and a total of 100k ADA was requested. If ADA’s price continues to be around $0.5, then the budget would be $50k and only 5 proposals would get funded. Although, this would be a very nice proposal anyways. It is mentioned that information about the students and their emails form their institutions would be used to verify that they really study there. It’s not a perfect solution, but it might work. The proposals would have to be focused on students’ start-ups or activities to foster them. Although it’s not guaranteed, I believe this challenge might help creating real-world solutions using Cardano blockchain, but other 3 goals of Cardano’s mission might be more challenging to address through this challenge setting. I believe the alignment of this proposal with Cardano’s mission is good.
f6_assessments.q1: The successful execution of this proposal depends on finding enough interested students to submit a good number of proposals (let’s say, at least 20) so the community could choose to fund the best among them. I believe this is possible, though some marketing and advertising would be necessary, especially because the time window between when results are out and the submission phase of the next fund are not so wide, usually a few weeks. During this time, it would be necessary to attract the attention of students and to have them start idealizing their projects using Cardano and to prepares a business plan in case they haven’t started doing so already. Since the budget of this challenge, at the end, is probably going to be around $50k, and not $100k as stated in the proposal, I believe it very likely that there will be enough submission in this proposal to make it feasible and good proposals would be chosen by the community.
f6_assessments.q2: The KPIs suggested to verify the success of this challenge proposal are not related to the final results of the challenge itself, but only to the stage of proposal submission: number of proposals submitted, applause and comments and collaborations. It would be necessary to include some information about the success of the proposals after they got funded, for example, how many projects of these start-ups were successfully developed, how many turned into a successful commercial business, or how many finished their first step but will re-apply for next fund (there is one KPI that mentions this but I’m not sure if it’s the same idea), i.e., metrics that would measure the outcome of the challenge, not only the participation and results before the proposals get funded. I believe the verifiability of the challenge based on the KPIs proposed is unfortunately not so good.
f6_assessments.reply:
The PA commented that you should add KPIs about the success of the proposals after they got funded. (Example, the number of successful projects developed by these start-ups, the number of successful projects in the commercial business) 
Indeed, my challenge proposal may have lacked KPIs for post-funded project audits. However, in that case, the number of project failures must also be included in the KPI. Because even if the proposed project fails, it can be a lot of learning. These experiences are invaluable learning, especially for students who are prone to failure. It's well worth reporting as a KPI. Therefore, I think it is a wrong hypothesis to add only the number of successful projects as a KPI.

f6_assessments.q0:
This proposal is a follow-up to the student challenge in fund 9.
I strongly agree about the need for a unique student challenge with a small proposed budget. This challenge will help a lot of students who love blockchain have a chance to start a business. The challenge is also geared towards a younger audience than high school students. This is great for encouraging and guiding high school students who can shape their future development.
f6_assessments.q1: The Catalyst ecosystem is increasingly diverse in terms of participants, in addition to many proposals related to educational programs and links with universities. So it will not be difficult for the current community to develop this challenge better and better. The proposed team details are still 2 members of the same challenge in fund 9. 1 person is now a student who will understand what students need help, 1 person is a Cardano ambassador and 1 representative. famous community in the Asian community. They are fully qualified to continue to take on a similar challenge in fund 10. The goals and directions for the proposals in the challenge are also clearer and more detailed than the content of the challenge in fund 9. The budget part completely matches the numerical goals that the challenge poses and is too reasonable compared to the total budget of fund 10.
f6_assessments.q2: Key metric includes 4 very clear goals and is only slightly different from the challenge in fund 9. The new key metric is "Number of collaborations with other proposers" which can also be considered an improvement and a challenge. However, I have a small suggestion, can add the key metric "Number of students or students team onboarding". It will give a clearer assessment of the success of this proposal as it can be seen as the next challenge of fund 9.

f6_assessments.q0: This challenge is clearly aligned with the Cardano objective, I find really important to give an opportunity to the entrepreneur students to express their ideas and also to support startups led by students. Students will be the main actors in this ecosystem in the future, there is a need for education and this is what this challenge is supporting. It is also aligned with the strategic goals for Fund 9.
f6_assessments.q1: This challenge might not be really accessible for all the community, but I find it a perfect opportunity for students to express their ideas. Moreover, this is a good opportunity for educating students and bring more impactful figures in the community. Concerning the budget, I like the fact that there is a budget cap of $10000 since it is enough to do one impactful proposal. This challenge was already there on fund 8 but had some different aspects, in this one, they upgraded the quality and it might work well.
f6_assessments.q2: The success metrics of the challenge aligned with the challenge needs and Cardano’s mission. The success is defined well in the area given by the challenge which is educating and integrating students in the community. Moreover, this challenge drives to a healthy competition between the proposers and also a collaboration between students and current community members.

f6_assessments.q0: The challenge setting proposal aims to “support student blockchain startups, increase student proposers and engineers”. This can be important to achieve F9 Strategic Goals of “attract more developers” and “prepare a group of people willing and able to  contribute”. The success described sounds more like the approach one should take to solve the focus of the challenge rather than the expected outcome. A more suitable description should be something along the lines of increasing the number of student proposers and more resources for student developers.
f6_assessments.q1: The Cardano community has the ability to solve the challenge proposed. The budget proposed is realistic and reflects the amount of work required for completing the proposal. Being a student myself, I’d first like to appreciate the team’s effort in bringing up this challenge proposal. The challenge fund would be used to initiate projects built by students. This is important as Project Catalyst challenges shifts its pivot from funding pre-project research to the project itself. Many students can’t acquire resources for their research, unlike other groups which are more likely to find other sources of fundings.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal described a few metrics, they are quite similar and in my opinion doesn’t reflect the whole picture of what success looks like. Other than considering student participation on Project Catalyst, other forms of participation should also be included, for example wallet created, student hubs built. I advise the challenge team to think more carefully about how success can be defined. However, I do see the potential in the proposal.

f6_assessments.q0:
The proposal is in line with the challenging objectives presented. I think this proposal will be necessary to solve the problem of solution building of the Student entrepreneurs group. This will attract a good amount of attention. A large group of students participate because the job demand that blockchain creates is quite large.
However, I believe that there will be obstacles in the conditions of participation due to the requirement to provide information to prove the student's identity. I think we need to be more flexible in this condition.
f6_assessments.q1: I think the student community will do well on this challenge. The challenge is to have business ideas that take advantage of blockchain. Which I think is possible when blockchain is gradually creeping into the world live every day and creating more demand to use blockchain. The total budget is 100000USD and limit per proposal is 10000USD so there will be at least 10 projects built => pretty good. I think it will attract a large number of voters.
f6_assessments.q2:
I add the criterion ""what does success look like?" that: success is the number of users participating in the proposal, the business idea of the student group. Besides, the main criteria to measure should add a few criteria such as:
- businesses participating in cooperation with the student group after the proposal
- job opportunities after the proposal is created.

f6_assessments.q0:
This challenge wants to support student blockchain startups and onboard student Catalyst proposers & blockchain engineers. Both ideas are good and will add value to the Cardano ecosystem.
The participation conditions will be helpful, especially in the case of startup proposals under this challenge, as it will require the proposer to include at least one student. Moreover, as mentioned, it will help them skip the competition from the experienced participants.
This challenge will help with the strategic goals. In the case of startups, it will help bring in able people willing to contribute to Cardano and prepare the students members with them. Furthermore, the solutions/products built with these startups will enhance the growth of the developer & DApp ecosystem. On the other hand, students' onboarding proposals will also prepare future Catalyst proposers and blockchain engineers who will do the above with the future proposals.
In either of the type of proposals, this challenge will add value and have a positive impact. Hence this challenge is essential for Cardano's mission.
f6_assessments.q1:
In Fund 9, there is a similar kind of challenge called 'Challenge & Scouted for Students.' The proposals submitted for that challenge is mostly 'outreach/onboarding students' proposals. It shows the community's enthusiasm and capability to address at least one part of this challenge. Regarding the student startups, I am skeptical about community participation. However, the proper conditions and requirements laid out by the author at least will help the students in becoming part of the proposals' team.
The asked budget of $100k is reasonable, and with the budget cap for each proposal, it will be sufficient for at least ten proposals.
The author currently serves in a challenge team for 'Challenge & Scouted for Students', and he is also a Cardano Ambassador; it shows that he is qualified to head the challenge team for this challenge if it is selected.
f6_assessments.q2:
The author stated four metrics:' the number of proposals under this category in this Fund,' 'the number of proposals in the next Fund,' 'the feedback from the community, and 'the number of proposals coordinated with other engineers.' All these metrics are helpful only to measure this challenge's success.
Regarding the proposal's metrics, the author did not mention any metrics. Hence there is room for improvement in this area. However, he did provide the expected type of proposals under this challenge. i.e., 1) Student Entrepreneur Startup 2) Students Onboarding to become future Catalyst Proposer & Blockchain Engineers. In the first case, the metrics can be the development updates on platforms such as GitHub or Jira board or via some reports. In the second case, the metrics can be the number of events conducted, the number of participants on such occasions, the number of views in the case of education content provided on social media, etc. In addition, the auditors can consider several other success metrics based on the type of proposals.

f6_assessments.q0:
This project will encourage young developers and entrepreneurs to take their first steps into building projects on the blockchain. 

By introducing new young talent to the Cardano ecosystem it will promote the use and adoption of Cardano for years to come and help encourage the great minds of the future to align with the core principles of Cardono. 

Therefore “start-ups and boarding students challenge” strongly aligns itself with fund 9 strategic goal 1. of preparing a group of people (in this case students) willing and able to make contributions to the cardano ecosystem (many students are looking for opportunities for their future and are prepared to learn and experiment). 

Goals 2,3 and 4 will be addressed simply by providing an opportunity for the next generation of developers, blockchain engineers and entrepreneurs to get involved with Cardano. 

Although in these areas the challenge does not align with the strategic goals as well as it does with goal 1. It will directly engage people who may build the future of the blockchain and Cardano itself. Therefore giving this challenge relevance to all fund 9 strategic goals.
f6_assessments.q1:
For this challenge proposal the proposers seem to have been reasonably conservative with the required budget.

They have set a limit to the amount of funding that can be requested per proposal allowing a greater number of projects to be funded within the overall budget. 

One of the aims of the proposal is to onboard students who will then participate in other challenges with larger budgets in future funds. 

This is a sensible approach. It allows students to gain experience and prove their ability to execute a funded project. Without risking a large proportion of treasury funds. 

Having gained a proven track record through this challenge setting the community will more likely to entrust larger funding amounts to these individuals if they propose in future funds.
 
The challenge proposers (both Cardano Ambassadors)have experience in all the relevant areas of Catalyst to help the community address this challenge. 

One of the team members is also a junior at Waseda University - Japan. This will help the team relate to the community of student proposers who would be requesting funding if this challenge is implemented.

The Catalyst community has many educators, entrepreneurs and developers who are willing to collaborate with and support good project ideas and help develop teams. This means the community has the capacity to address this challenge.
f6_assessments.q2:
This proposed challenge has easily measured kpi’s and has by design a minimum number of funded projects. 

If the challenge is not adopted for fund 10 it may be advantageous to describe how the student communities will be made aware of the funding opportunity. Also the number of different universities/colleges proposers are affiliated to may be a useful addition to the kpi’s as this would help show the geographical distribution of funds.

f6_assessments.q0: I support this challenge because it encourages the development of ideas and projects from students. Students are always an important resource for the future.  Students normally have ideas and time but lack experience. Projects written by students can hardly be compared with those written by experienced proposers. Thus, there should be a separate place for them to innovate their ideas. This challenge fits well with the Strategic goals of fund 9 which is “Prepare a group of people willing and able to make contributions to the ecosystem”, “Build real-world solutions based on the Cardano blockchain”, and “attract more developers”. For this reason, I rate 5 stars for this Alignment category.
f6_assessments.q1: Since this is a continuation of Challenge & Scouted for Students in Fund 9, I am sure the community will have all the skills needed to evaluate this challenge. In Fund 9, this challenge attracted 36 proposals from all over the world, which proves that it has inspired projects written by students. For Fund 10, the total budget is still $100.000, but the budget for one proposal has increased from $5000 to $10,000. I think the author wants to support more ideas with bigger funds from students. When the budget is more, there would be people who are actually not students but want to participate in this challenge. I think the Participation conditions of this challenge are pretty loose because only one member of the team needs to be a student, and the rest of the members are not needed to be students. I think it is possible to tighten the Regulation by requiring all members to be students.
f6_assessments.q2: I think the metrics the author gives for this challenge are perfectly reasonable. Especially I like the metric “Number of proposals that participated in the next fund”. I think it's a good indicator to measure the development of projects from students, and thus the development of this challenge. “Number of collaborations with other proposers” is a pretty good metric, but I just wondering how to measure this. If possible the author should go into more detail about how to measure it.

f6_assessments.q0:
Students are a great potential community because they have time, creativity, and innovation. However, they have limitations in knowledge and practical experience. Therefore, it is tough for students to compete with others who have deep knowledge and experience in Cardano and blockchain, and their proposals have less chance to be funded. This will prevent students from joining and contributing to the Cattalyts ecosystem.  
This challenge will create a private space for students to compete fairly with each other so that they have more chances to be funded. I think this is a great opportunity for excellent students to participate and contribute to the community. 
This challenge is in line with the goal of “Preparing a group of people willing and able to make contributions to the ecosystem”, and “attracting more developers” - the strategic goals of the fund 9 challenge setting.
Based on the above analysis I rate this Challenge 5 points in the Alignment category.
f6_assessments.q1:
This challenge is a continuation of the Challenge & Scouted for Students in Fund 9. Currently, the Challenge & Scouted for Students has attracted 49 proposals, more than 4,000  proposal views, and 90 comments. So I think there are a lot of real resources and ideas which are ready to address this challenge. 
We may worry about whether students can solve the problem adequately and properly. However, the participation condition of this challenge is that at least one member is a student. That means membership can include experienced non-students, they can complement the students' shortcomings and support each other to implement and finish the proposal well. 
The budget for the challenge is 100,000 USD, and the maximum budget for a proposal is set at 10,000 USD. I think the 10,000 USD budget is adequate and suitable for student proposals. However, as mentioned above the Challenge & Scouted for Students in Fund 9 has attracted many potential proposals, and this number may increase in Fund 10. Therefore,  the author should also consider increasing the budget for the challenge up to 200,000 USD. 
Based on the above analysis I rate this Challenge 5 points in the Feasibility category.
f6_assessments.q2:
The author gives 4 metrics to measure the success of the challenge including Number of proposals for this category; Number of applause and comments from the community; Number of collaborations with other proposers; Number of proposals that participated in the next fund. These metrics are great at measuring the appeal of the challenge to the community in general. In order to better assess the level of student participation in proposals, I think the author should consider adding some metrics such as Number of proposers who are students; Percentage of team members who are students. etc.
Based on the above analysis I rate this Challenge 4 points in the Verifiability category.

f6_assessments.q0: They are the future knowledge components, so being oriented and giving students an environment where they can be creative is important. Students are a great resource, with a very agile approach to knowledge and learning. Catalyst must pay attention to, and provide support for, the important challenge of assisting individuals in developing themselves and encouraging individuals to begin their own businesses. As a result, in my opinion, this obstacle is significant, and Catalyst absolutely needs to find a solution to it. It is appropriate to provide students with a setting in which they can cultivate their way of thinking and working because, in the future, this will be a workforce that has the potential to change everything, including the future of the country. It is a good idea for you to put a cap on the amount of $10,000 that can be requested for a student proposal. Doing so helps a large number of students, specifically more than ten proposals can be funded if the challenge that you are attempting to complete is successful.
f6_assessments.q1: Due to the fact that you have stated as a requirement that a member of the group must either be a student or a student, or be a PhD student in order to be accepted, it goes without saying that other members may be experts; consequently, it is reasonable for students to combine with experts in order to receive direction and instruction from those who have more experience. Issa Ichikawa, another student, is the current proponent for Fund 10. She has previous experience with Fund 6, demonstrating that she is an active person and that she is quite capable of achieving success in the difficult task of placing, and she is the person who is in charge of the fund. away with this.
f6_assessments.q2: Your success criterion is to reduce the competition among proposals by limiting the number of proposals to students, and limit the amount to less than 1 million yen for a proposal, so there are many proposals. can be funded, specifically over 10 proposals. The indicators to measure this challenge are given by you with 4 main criteria. And I would like to contribute 1 more sub-index: number of funded projects as well as practical application in real life. live, number of ongoing projects and number of completed projects in previous funds through the challenge. From those main and secondary criteria can help the community evaluate and measure the quality and progress of the challenge you set.

f6_assessments.q0:
Students are people with a lot of energy and ideas. What they lack is only experience and knowledge, and advice from experienced advisors.
The contributions of students may not be much to the development of Cardano, but in the future, they will be a continued resource to help Cardano go further in fulfilling its mission.
This challenge is crucial in making Cardano's future operating model sustainable and efficient.
What we need to do now are sponsored proposals with simple, easy-to-implement ideas that will inspire and motivate young students to develop their careers on Cardano. Help them know Cardano's potential and believe in Cardano's future growth. Let them confidently put their future careers in Cardano and contribute to creating a civilized, innovative and sustainable Cardano ecosystem.
I am a big supporter of this Challenge and look forward to this Challenge continuing to be funded in other funding rounds.
f6_assessments.q1:
This is a Challenge with simple requirements. So students participating in the Catalyst community can easily participate in proposal writing.
However, authors should carefully review and monitor funded proposals that work. What other emerging problems should we consider?
To find suitable solutions and stronger criteria to improve the quality of funding proposals.
I want to see Catalyst-funded coins work and not go to waste.
f6_assessments.q2:
Regarding the author's funding budget, I find it unreasonable to increase the $10,000 limit for a proposal. Why?
Because the students are the ones who still lack a lot of experience in planning, financial management and do not foresee the risks.
Giving students too much money is not a good thing. When they have less money, they are more creative and find more creative solutions to problems.
I was also a student, so I understand very well the danger when students are funded with too much money. Since they still lack a lot of experience and knowledge, their current contribution to Cardano is not great. So give them a small amount of money so they can implement simple yet effective ideas so that they step up to more complex challenges that are within their reach.
I judge the picture to be successful because the author needs to make it more transparent and stronger. For example, there will be many students at the university who know Catalyst or Cardano and participate in Catalyst activities, for example.
Regarding the success index, I think it is necessary to add important indicators such as increasing the number of students participating in Catalyst, increasing the number of students using applications on Cardano.
Those are the results that show the impact of students on Cardano's development instead of too general indicators.
I hope the author will think about what I contribute and add to my Challenge.

importance: Student entrepreneurs lack the resources needed to startup. And Cardano ecosystem also requires young Catalyst proposers and engineers.
success: Reduce the competition rate by limiting the proposers to students. And set a budget cap and distribute opportunities to many proposers.
